title: 115_s2362
content: The Act may be cited as the "Control Your Personal Credit Information Act of 2018". Permissible purposes of reports are outlined in the Act. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to require consumer consent for the furnishing of consumer reports for specific purposes like credit extensions and insurance underwriting. Consumer reporting agencies can furnish consumer reports for reviewing or collecting on accounts with affirmative written consent from the consumer. Reports can be provided for credit or insurance transactions not initiated by the consumer if the consumer gives written consent. The consumer can elect to have their name and addresses included in lists provided by the reporting agency for credit or insurance transactions not initiated by them, with proper identification and consent. The consumer can provide written consent for the consumer reporting agency to furnish a report for a firm offer of credit or insurance and can revoke this election at any time. Additionally, the agency is restricted from providing inquiry records to individuals, except as specified in section 609(a)(5). The agency is prohibited from disclosing inquiry records for credit or insurance transactions not initiated by the consumer. To procure a consumer report for certain purposes, a clear written disclosure must be provided to the consumer beforehand, and their authorization is required. The Control Your Personal Credit Information Act of 2018 requires written authorization from the consumer for procuring a consumer report. The Director of the Bureau must establish regulations within 180 days of enactment, including a model form for disclosure documents and guidelines for clear and conspicuous disclosures. The Act requires guidelines for consumers to authorize multiple users for a specific time period, mandates consumer reporting agencies to provide a secure method for consumers to control the sharing of their reports, and sets a deadline for agencies to remove a consumer's information upon request. Consumer reporting agencies must provide a secure method for consumers to control the sharing of their reports, without collecting unnecessary information or advertising products/services. Consumers cannot be required to waive rights or indemnify agencies when using this method. The Control Your Personal Credit Information Act of 2018 requires the Director of the Bureau to submit reports to the Senate and House committees within 180 days of enactment, after consulting with various regulators. The House of Representatives recommendations aim to enhance transparency and control for consumers regarding their consumer reports. The Director of the Bureau is required to submit an annual report to the Senate and House committees with recommendations for improvement and details on enforcement actions taken for compliance. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on additional protections needed for secure consumer information in files, ensuring no adverse impact on consumers. A report must be submitted within 1 year. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to the Senate and House committees within 1 year of the enactment of the Control Your Personal Credit Information Act of 2018, presenting clear conclusions and recommendations for legislative changes to safeguard consumer information. The Control Your Personal Credit Information Act of 2018 requires the Comptroller General to submit a report to Congress within one year, with recommendations for legislative changes to protect consumer information. This includes ensuring the security of consumer files and prohibiting consumer reporting agencies from charging fees for certain activities. The Act mandates consumer reporting agencies to prevent unauthorized access to consumer reports and information. Regulations will ensure disclosure of consumer information upon written request, regardless of the agency's affiliation. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to make technical and conforming changes, including updating references to specific sections within the Act. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to update references to specific sections within the Act, such as changing "604(e)" to "604(c)(5)(D)" and "subsection (c) or (e) of section 604" to "604(c)".
